Table of Contents
Applicable Periods of Limitation for NRN Requests
Procedures for Appeals
page (
) Purpose: This IRM section provides guidance to ensure consistency for Appeals employees processing and working Net Rate Netting (NRN) cases. Speciﬁcally, IRM

: a. Provides an overview of interest netting and types of NRN requests b. Explains Appeals’ criteria for accepting a NRN request from the Ogden Campus c. Describes the actions required by the Appeals Complex Interest Team (CIT) for NRN requests received from the Ogden Campus d. Describes actions required by Appeals Technical Employees when working standalone NRN requests or NRN requests for liability periods open in Appeals e. Recommends resources, including legal references, Revenue Proce- dures, and other IRM sections (
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM section are Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs) working NRN cases and the Appeals CIT Lead Tax Examiner. (
) Policy Owner: Policy, Planning, Quality, and Analysis is under the Director, Case and Operations Support. (

) Program Owner: Appeals Policy is the program office responsible for technical and procedural guidance to the Appeals organization and is under the Director of Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis. (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established on How to Contact an Analyst. Other employees should contact the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM section. (

) Appeals’ mission is to resolve tax controversies, without litigation, on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer in a manner that will enhance voluntary compliance and public conﬁdence in the integrity and efficiency of the Service. Appeals accomplishes this mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights, Pub
, Taxpayer Bill Rights, and IRM
, Accomplishing the Appeals Mission. (

) When a taxpayer is charged interest on an underpayment during the same period of time interest is allowed on an overpayment, the procedure used IRS to equalize the interest rate differential is called interest netting. Interest netting is authorized by IRC Section
(d). See IRM
, Authority. (
) Per Revenue Procedure
, the Service will take reasonable steps to identify overlapping periods of tax overpayments and underpayments and apply the net interest rate of zero to interest accruing on or after October

Because the Service is currently unable to automatically apply the net interest rate of zero, there may be instances when the Service fails to periods of overlap and apply the net interest rate of zero. To ensure that taxpayers receive the beneﬁt of the net interest rate of zero in all applicable situations, taxpayers should request the net interest rate of zero (or request the Service to recompute the net interest rate of zero if the taxpayer with a Service computation of the net interest rate of zero) on or before the Internal Revenue Manual

) Appeals’ mission is to resolve tax controversies, without litigation, on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer in a manner that will enhance voluntary compliance and public conﬁdence in the integrity and efficiency of the Service. Appeals accomplishes this mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. ), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights, Pub

) When a taxpayer is charged interest on an underpayment during the same period of time interest is allowed on an overpayment, the procedure used by IRS to equalize the interest rate differential is called interest netting. Interest netting is authorized by IRC Section
(d). See IRM
, Authority. (
) Per Revenue Procedure
, the Service will take reasonable steps to identify overlapping periods of tax overpayments and underpayments and apply the net interest rate of zero to interest accruing on or after October

Because the Service is currently unable to automatically apply the net interest rate of zero, there may be instances when the Service fails to identify periods of overlap and apply the net interest rate of zero. To ensure that taxpayers receive the beneﬁt of the net interest rate of zero in all applicable situations, taxpayers should request the net interest rate of zero (or request the Service to recompute the net interest rate of zero if the taxpayer with a Service computation of the net interest rate of zero) on or before the Internal Revenue Manual
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
date on which the last applicable period of limitation described in IRM 8.7.19.4, Applicable Periods of Limitation for NRN Requests.
) IRC Section
requires the Internal Revenue Service to pay interest on any tax overpayment when the requirements of IRC Section
are met. IRC Section
requires taxpayers to pay interest on any tax underpayment. Interest is computed at the rates established under IRC Section
) for overpayments and IRC Section
) for underpayments. IRC Section
(c) provides for an increase in underpayment rate for large corporate un- derpayments. IRC Section
(d) provides that to the extent that, for any interest computation period, interest is payable under IRC Section
and allowable under IRC Section
on equivalent underpayments and overpay- ments by the same taxpayer of tax imposed under the Internal Revenue Code, the net rate of interest will be zero for that interest computation period.

, Netting of Overpayment and Underpayment Interest. The following table lists helpful IRM sections on the computation of interest:

, the Service will take reasonable steps to identify overlapping interest computation periods of tax and underpayments and apply the net interest rate of zero in IRC Section

To ensure that taxpayers receive the beneﬁt of the net interest rate of zero in all applicable situations, taxpayers should request the net interest rate of zero (or request the Service to recompute the net interest rate of zero if the taxpayer with a Service computation of the net interest rate of zero) on or before the date on which the last applicable period of limitation closes and according to the procedures in Section

8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
) Net rate netting under IRC Section

(d) is available only when there exists overlapping periods of overpayment and underpayment by the same taxpayer upon which interest is both payable and allowable. Prior to the time an over- payment or underpayment is determined for a tax period, there is no principal upon which interest can be computed and a request for zero-netting is premature. (

) When a NRN request is received by the Accounts Management (AM) Interest Team (CIT) at the Ogden Campus, that site will ensure that the NRN request properly identiﬁes the taxpayer, the taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN), the overlapping underpayment and overpayment amount(s) and and the tax years and type(s) of overpayment and underpayment taxes involved. The AM CIT will perform IDRS research (TXMOD and CFOL) on all tax periods included in the NRN request to determine if any tax period has an open AIMS “L” freeze, which is an indicator of Examination or Appeals in- volvement. Note: If there is no “L” Freeze and/or no Examination or Appeals involvement, AM CIT will process the request for the resolved tax period(s). (
) If there is an “L” freeze and the AIMS status code is
, or

for any of the NRN request tax period(s), the AM CIT will take the following steps to determine if Appeals will accept the NRN request for the tax liability periods controlled by Appeals for the same taxpayer: a. Send an email to Appeals *AP Complex Interest, and include the following “note” in the subject line: “Open AIMS Netting Case”. b. Include the Taxpayer(s) Name, EIN/TIN, MFTs and all years included in the claim. c. Specify which tax period is “open” in Appeals. d. The Appeals CIT Lead will contact the Appeals Technical Employee assigned the case to determine if the case will be closed within
days. If the case is going to be closed within
-days, Appeals will accept the request. If the case is not going to be closed within

-days, Appeals not accept the request. e. If the request is accepted, the Appeals CIT Lead will advise the AM CIT Appeals will accept the NRN request and will forward it to the address provided by the Appeals CIT lead. f. After advising the AM CIT that Appeals will accept the NRN request, Appeals CIT Lead will import the case into Appeals Processing Automated System (PEAS) and make the following entries on PEAS: - Input the PC (post closure) feature code; - Type = CLS - Sub-type = NET - Assign it to the appropriate CIT PTM (based on the CIT Lead currently working case assignments) - Set a follow-up date for
days from the date of assignment. If the is not received within
days, the PTM will follow-up with the ATE. Note: Normal assignment practices will resume upon notiﬁcation from ATE that the case is ready to be sent to APS/CIT.

overlapping periods of overpayment and underpayment by the same taxpayer upon which interest is both payable and allowable. Prior to the time an over- payment or underpayment is determined for a tax period, there is no principal upon which interest can be computed and a request for zero-netting is premature. (

) When a NRN request is received by the Accounts Management (AM) Complex Interest Team (CIT) at the Ogden Campus, that site will ensure that the NRN request properly identiﬁes the taxpayer, the taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN), the overlapping underpayment and overpayment amount(s) and date(s), and the tax years and type(s) of overpayment and underpayment taxes involved. The AM CIT will perform IDRS research (TXMOD and CFOL) on all tax periods included in the NRN request to determine if any tax period has an open AIMS “L” freeze, which is an indicator of Examination or Appeals in- volvement.
Note: If there is no “L” Freeze and/or no Examination or Appeals involvement, the AM CIT will process the request for the resolved tax period(s).

Procedures for Appeals
page (

) Amounts are resolved when the principal amount is no longer subject to con- troversy in Exam, Appeals, or a court. An unresolved amount is a principal amount that is still under consideration in Exam, Appeals or a court. net rate netting cannot be computed prior to the time that an overpayment or underpayment amount is determined for a tax period. (

) NRN is an Appeals Coordinated Issue (ACI). An ACI is an issue or category case with Service-wide impact or importance, requiring coordination to ensure uniformity and consistency nationwide. ACIs along with the assigned Specialist are listed on the Appeals Web site in the Domestic/International erations “Issue Locator”. For the public, they are also listed at www.irs.gov/ appeals. (
) The ATE is responsible for preparing and forwarding a referral, through the Appeals Team Manager, to Appeals’ Technical Guidance on Form
, Appeals Technical Guidance Referral, when the case has an ACI. In addition, the ACDS Feature Code “AI” (for Appeals Coordinated Issue) must be included on ACDS. See IRM
, Domestic and International Operations, the ACDS Utilities / Feature Code Lookup. (

) A Technical Guidance Specialist will review the NRN request and assist the ATE in determining whether to return the request, retain it in the ﬁle for eration with a related case with unresolved principal amount(s), or to consider the standalone NRN request. For more information, see IRM
, Appeals Technical Specialists’ Roles and Responsibilities. Note: For standalone NRN requests, when APS receives the case, follow card-in guidance in IRM
, Net Rate Netting (NRN) Claim/Request Carding. (
) After considering the NRN request, the ATE will select the appropriate closing letter based on actions previously taken for the request. See IRM
, Closing Letters for Disposition of Claims. IRM
, Applicable Periods of Limitations for NRN Requests, contains information on the period of limitation for ﬁling a refund claim and for ﬁling a refund suit for debit interest under
of the U. S. Code versus the period for requesting credit interest under Title

) The taxpayer or authorized representative can ﬁle a NRN claim by writing on top of Form

” and by providing documentation to substantiate the taxpayer’s to receive interest due on the overpayment. It is not necessary for the to provide a dollar amount. For more information, see Form
Instructions and Revenue Procedure

Rate Netting Procedures for Appeals 8.7.19
) Revenue Procedure
, Section

contains information on the appli- cable periods of limitation as follows: of a. Underpayment interest (“Debit Interest”). A claim for credit or refund of NRN interest paid on an underpayment pursuant to IRC Sections

or generally must be ﬁled within three years from the time the tax return was ﬁled or two years from the time the interest was paid, whichever period expires later. Note: Claims for refund of “debit interest” fall under Title
of the U.S. Code. See IRM
, Periods of Limitation in Claim and Over- assessment Cases, for applicable tax law sections. Per IRC Section

, Periods of Limitation on Suits, the two-year period ﬁling a refund suit begins on the date IRS sends (by certiﬁed or regular mail) a notice of disallowance or the taxpayer waives the requirement for the mailing of the notice of disallowance. IRC Section
limits the time for making a refund or credit of an overpayment. See IRM
, Limitations on Refunds or of Overpayments. b. Overpayment interest (“Credit Interest”). A claim for payment of interest allowable on an overpayment pursuant to IRC Section
be ﬁled within the six-year period in which a suit must be ﬁled pursuant to
U.S.C. Sections
, Time for Commencing Acting Against the United States, and
, Time for Filing Suit. See Rev. Rul.

of Revenue Procedure

and

Underpayment interest (“Debit Interest”). A claim for credit or refund of interest paid on an underpayment pursuant to IRC Sections
or
generally must be ﬁled within three years from the time the tax return was ﬁled or two years from the time the interest was paid, whichever period expires later.
Claims for refund of “debit interest” fall under Title
of the U.S. Code. See IRM

, Periods of Limitation on Suits, the two-year period for ﬁling a refund suit begins on the date IRS sends (by certiﬁed or regular mail) a notice of disallowance or the taxpayer waives the requirement for the mailing of the notice of disallowance. IRC Section
limits the time for making a refund or credit of an overpayment. See IRM
, Limitations on Refunds or Credits of Overpayments.
Overpayment interest (“Credit Interest”). A claim for payment of interest allowable on an overpayment pursuant to IRC Section

of Revenue Procedure

U.S.C. Sections
and

U.S.C. Sections
and
See Rev. Rul.
C.B.
A claim for payment of credit interest is not a refund claim. Therefore, the time limits described in IRM
, Periods of Limitation in Claim and Over- assessment Cases, don’t apply. This request falls under Title
of the U.S. Code. The time for ﬁling suit is six years, and IRC Section
does not apply.
